BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 23, 1923

THEY'RE OFF
be furnished tomorrow night when the
should
Thrills aplenty
annual Fifth Regiment-Johns Hopkins meet takes place. Three hundred athletes have journeyed to Baltimore to put themselves against
the two hundred and fifty local entrants on the path and afield. The
collection includes a number of nationally famous cinderpath stars
and a few football players of All-American selection.
Although the Hopkins track organization has been sorely hit by
graduation and by the blacklist, the survivors are giving an excellent
account of themselves. These men are deserving of all the praise that
Hopkins can give them.
There are a number of reasons why the meet, tomorrow night,
should be a particularly worthwhile affair. Practically all of the athletes of note who were entered in the Georgetown meet, will be entered then and are on exhibition, our management points out, for half
the price of the Washington meet. One of the greatest features will
be probably the medley relay in which Booth will run as anchor man
for the Black and Blue. All eyes will be leveled upon this lanky
youth who attracted national attention by defeating the famous flash,
Joie Ray, at Georgetown, Wednesday night.
All lovers of excitement of the three-ring circus variety will find
it at the Armory tomorrow night. With revolvers snapping from
every corner, athletes "warming up" wherever space is available,
groups of field-event men going through their paces, and scores of
judges, dispatchers and other officials bristling with importance,
thoughts of Barnum and Bailey's little offering seems tame.
This is Hopkins one big major event between the Thanksgiving
football game and the first lacrosse contest. What a flurry, what
yelling, what excitement,—
THEY'RE OFF!•

JUNE WEEK
Those who do not know just what June Week is going to offer
this year, had better find out in short order and start saving for the
price of a ticket or else they will be sadly disappointed when that
week of joy rolls around.
Never before has a real Senior extravaganza such as that to be
offered in June ever been attempted at Hopkins. An entire week of
solid joy—music, athletics, banqueting, comedy and dancing galore,
terminating
,•.in the final Senior ball and banquet with a million dollar
imported jazz band aiding the graduates to break the ties of college
life without shedding a tear.
A3solid week of joy at the rate of about a dollar a day!

OUTDOOR WORK IN PHYSICAL TRAINING TO BE
RESUMED SOON
The outdoor physical training
classes for both Freshmen and
Sophomores will reopen about the
last of March, or as soon thereafter as possible. Dr. Abercrombie, director of physical education
is now giving his lectures on Personal Hygiene to all students of
the University who have not heretofore received them, but these
are now more than half completed
All are illustrated.
The lectures, as well as the outdoor classes, are given on Monday, Wednesday and Friday of
each week. This year the outdoor
classes have mainly been supervised by the Military Department,
under the supervision of Major
Enoch B. Garey.

"WORD MONGER S"and
CHATTERING BARBERS"
"Word mongers" and "chattering barbers," Gilbert
called those of his predecessors who asser‘ted that a
wound made by a magnetized needle was painless, that
a magnet will attract silver, that the diamond will draw
iron, that the magnet thirsts and dies in the absence of
iron, that a magnet, pulverized and taken with sweetened water, will cure headaches and prevent fat.
Before Gilbert died in 1603, he had done much to explain magnetism and electricity through experiment. He
found that by hammering iron held in a magnetic
meridian it can be magnetized. He discovered that the
compass needle•is controlled by the earth's magnetism
and that one magnet can remagnetize another that has
lost its power. He noted the common electrical attraction of rubbed bodies, among them diamonds, as well
as glass, crystals, and stones, and was the first to study
electricity as a distinct force.
"Not in books, but in things themselves, look for
knowledge," he shouted. This man helped to revolutionize methods of thinking—helped to make electricity what it has become. His fellow men were little
concerned with him and his experiments. "Will Queen
Elizabeth marry—and whom ?" they were asking.
Elizabeth's flirtations mean little to us. Gilbert's
method means much. It is the method that has made
modern electricity what it has become, the method which
enabled the Research Laboratories of the General
Electric Company to discover new electrical principles
now applied in transmitting power for hundreds of miles,
in lighting homes electrically, in aiding physicians with
the X-rays, in freeing civilization from drudgery.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 23, 1923

THEY'RE OFF
be furnished tomorrow night when the
should
Thrills aplenty
annual Fifth Regiment-Johns Hopkins meet takes place. Three hundred athletes have journeyed to Baltimore to put themselves against
the two hundred and fifty local entrants on the path and afield. The
collection includes a number of nationally famous cinderpath stars
and a few football players of All-American selection.
Although the Hopkins track organization has been sorely hit by
graduation and by the blacklist, the survivors are giving an excellent
account of themselves. These men are deserving of all the praise that
Hopkins can give them.
There are a number of reasons why the meet, tomorrow night,
should be a particularly worthwhile affair. Practically all of the athletes of note who were entered in the Georgetown meet, will be entered then and are on exhibition, our management points out, for half
the price of the Washington meet. One of the greatest features will
be probably the medley relay in which Booth will run as anchor man
for the Black and Blue. All eyes will be leveled upon this lanky
youth who attracted national attention by defeating the famous flash,
Joie Ray, at Georgetown, Wednesday night.
All lovers of excitement of the three-ring circus variety will find
it at the Armory tomorrow night. With revolvers snapping from
every corner, athletes "warming up" wherever space is available,
groups of field-event men going through their paces, and scores of
judges, dispatchers and other officials bristling with importance,
thoughts of Barnum and Bailey's little offering seems tame.
This is Hopkins one big major event between the Thanksgiving
football game and the first lacrosse contest. What a flurry, what
yelling, what excitement,—
THEY'RE OFF!•

JUNE WEEK
Those who do not know just what June Week is going to offer
this year, had better find out in short order and start saving for the
price of a ticket or else they will be sadly disappointed when that
week of joy rolls around.
Never before has a real Senior extravaganza such as that to be
offered in June ever been attempted at Hopkins. An entire week of
solid joy—music, athletics, banqueting, comedy and dancing galore,
terminating
,•.in the final Senior ball and banquet with a million dollar
imported jazz band aiding the graduates to break the ties of college
life without shedding a tear.
A3solid week of joy at the rate of about a dollar a day!

OUTDOOR WORK IN PHYSICAL TRAINING TO BE
RESUMED SOON
The outdoor physical training
classes for both Freshmen and
Sophomores will reopen about the
last of March, or as soon thereafter as possible. Dr. Abercrombie, director of physical education
is now giving his lectures on Personal Hygiene to all students of
the University who have not heretofore received them, but these
are now more than half completed
All are illustrated.
The lectures, as well as the outdoor classes, are given on Monday, Wednesday and Friday of
each week. This year the outdoor
classes have mainly been supervised by the Military Department,
under the supervision of Major
Enoch B. Garey.

GILBERT

PE

MsiGIVET- E

"WORD MONGER S"and
CHATTERING BARBERS"
"Word mongers" and "chattering barbers," Gilbert
called those of his predecessors who asser‘ted that a
wound made by a magnetized needle was painless, that
a magnet will attract silver, that the diamond will draw
iron, that the magnet thirsts and dies in the absence of
iron, that a magnet, pulverized and taken with sweetened water, will cure headaches and prevent fat.
Before Gilbert died in 1603, he had done much to explain magnetism and electricity through experiment. He
found that by hammering iron held in a magnetic
meridian it can be magnetized. He discovered that the
compass needle•is controlled by the earth's magnetism
and that one magnet can remagnetize another that has
lost its power. He noted the common electrical attraction of rubbed bodies, among them diamonds, as well
as glass, crystals, and stones, and was the first to study
electricity as a distinct force.
"Not in books, but in things themselves, look for
knowledge," he shouted. This man helped to revolutionize methods of thinking—helped to make electricity what it has become. His fellow men were little
concerned with him and his experiments. "Will Queen
Elizabeth marry—and whom ?" they were asking.
Elizabeth's flirtations mean little to us. Gilbert's
method means much. It is the method that has made
modern electricity what it has become, the method which
enabled the Research Laboratories of the General
Electric Company to discover new electrical principles
now applied in transmitting power for hundreds of miles,
in lighting homes electrically, in aiding physicians with
the X-rays, in freeing civilization from drudgery.
